    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1345 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1343 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1088 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Merging new-interface branch (667:957) to trunk
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Keyword 'old' has been removed.  The 'mix' keyword is now a tuple of three numbers:
    
    * the mixing coefficient
    * the number of old densities
    * parameter used for special metric.
    
    If the special metric parameter is x, then long wavelength changes are weighed x times higher than short wavelengths.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@557 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Cleaned up demo/H.py.
    Fixed nasty bug in initial random wave functions.
    Removed wrong docstring in density_mixer.py.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@454 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6514 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6119 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introducing a concept of 'Kohn-Sham layouts' which is to be responsible for parallel interplay between band and domain communicator layouts of the Kohn-Sham representation in both LCAO and FD mode. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix the way hooks are run and add a 'crashed' hook
    
    This is my working .gpaw/rc.py, which commits both crashed and converged
    results to my local database:
    
    0rams={
        "keywords":["gpaw"],
        "description": "Automatic",
    }
    
    def converged(calc):
        params["keywords"].append("converged")
        calc.write(".db", cmr_params=params)
    
    def crashed(calc):
        params["keywords"].append("crashed")
        calc.write(".db", cmr_params=params)

    Introduce keyword 'parallel' to GPAW, which should later replace
    'parsize', 'parsize_bands' and 'parstride_bands'.  This is a dictionary
    much like 'convergence' used to specify parallel options.  Parallel
    options for scalapack can now be specified this way.  More options to be
    added as necessary.

    wavefunctions objects now get an orbital descriptor, too, as it is used
    during initialization.  Avoid using extra_parameters everywhere to check
    for blacs (doing that still works, but is not mandatory anymore)

    Fixed bug related to keyword argument utility.

    Remove some of the redundant kwargs from set.
    
    Running calc.set(key=value) twice shouldn't delete all the
    wavefunctions etc. the second time.
    
    This fix only works for some of the simpler kwargs.
    From the list of "drastic changes": paw.py line 159:
                if key in ['lmax', 'width', 'stencils', 'external', 'xc']:
                    self.hamiltonian = None
                    self.occupations = None
                elif key in ['charge']:
                    self.hamiltonian = None
                    self.density = None
                elif key in ['kpts', 'nbands']:
                    self.wfs = EmptyWaveFunctions()
                    self.occupations = None
                elif key in ['h', 'gpts', 'setups', 'spinpol', 'usesymm',
                             'parsize', 'parsize_bands', 'parstride_bands',
                             'communicator']:
                    self.density = None
                    self.occupations = None
                    self.hamiltonian = None
                    self.wfs = EmptyWaveFunctions()
                elif key in ['mode', 'basis']:
                    self.wfs = EmptyWaveFunctions()
    
    I think only kpts, external, and communicator are not caught.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1941 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added lcao force calculation code.  Will not be initialized by default.  Supports multiple k-points and spins.  Density and potentials are now updated before force calculation (for grid forces too).
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1937 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1709 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1346 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1203 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    GLLB will now use orbital_dependent as it should be.
    
    I cleaned up, structured and commented the GLLB code, this makes it easier to add new options later (for
    example orbital dependent correlation functionals).
    
    This is by no means the final version, the XCCorrections part still needs to be cleaned up and the GLLB
    functional needs to be tested.
    
    I will perform a group of tests to test this new functional, I will discuss the results later when I have
    them. The atomization energies would be a good benchmark, but the spin-polarized calculation is still
    missing. I recall that there was discussion about converting the 1D-code to spin-polarized, is that going
    on? I think it would be rather easy thing as far as all_electron.py is consired, but hard when one needs to
    consider generator.py also.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1119 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@855 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For molecules (where we use zero electronic temperature) the fermi level is not well defined.
    Instead of returning an arbitrary number (100 Hartrees), I think the get_fermi_level method of paw should return 0.0, i.e. the vacuum level. Thus methods using Calculator.GetFermiLevel() will give meaningfull values for molecules also.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@592 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello! This is my first check in, so I hope that I won't crash anything.
    Here is the all electron KLI-functional that I have implemented. Feel free to comment
    and make suggestions.
    
    Few things that I should mention:
    1. I introduced xc.orbital_dependent flag, that is used for KLI-functional. This
    creates an alternative structure to xc.hybrid, so there might be a place
    to make code more uniform
    
    2.
    The KLI-potential cannot calculated every step, since that kind of calculation
    didn't converge.
    
    3.
    The code is still in developing stage, but I wanted to make this commit to
    see if I am going in to the right direction.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@567 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Keyword 'old' has been removed.  The 'mix' keyword is now a tuple of three numbers:
    
    * the mixing coefficient
    * the number of old densities
    * parameter used for special metric.
    
    If the special metric parameter is x, then long wavelength changes are weighed x times higher than short wavelengths.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@557 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added some text describing parallelizing over k-points.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@535 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    New LDAx functional (LDA exchange only).
    
    Moved exx stuff around.  Same EXX class is now used for both self-consistent and non self-consistent exx.  Self-consistent exx seems to work for all-electron calculations, but not quite for PAW.  Note also that it may not work in parallel mode.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@523 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Ensured that the total energy is also stored in the first two iterations.
    This has no practical effect, but is nice for debugging purposes.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@513 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@496 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restarting from a file with no wave functions triggered an immediate initialization of the wave functions from atomic ones.  This is now delayed to the time where the wave functions are actually needed.  The tar-file restart file format has been changed to use 32-bit integers for Int arrays.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@494 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6151 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introducing a concept of 'Kohn-Sham layouts' which is to be responsible for parallel interplay between band and domain communicator layouts of the Kohn-Sham representation in both LCAO and FD mode. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6355 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introduce keyword 'parallel' to GPAW, which should later replace
    'parsize', 'parsize_bands' and 'parstride_bands'.  This is a dictionary
    much like 'convergence' used to specify parallel options.  Parallel
    options for scalapack can now be specified this way.  More options to be
    added as necessary.
    
    Create OrbitalDescriptor in paw.py when parameters are parsed. FD-mode
    wavefunctions objects now get an orbital descriptor, too, as it is used
    during initialization.  Avoid using extra_parameters everywhere to check
    for blacs (doing that still works, but is not mandatory anymore)

    Added a minor docstring explaining what transformers.py and operators.py actually do.
    
    operators.py should be renamed to fd_operatos.py (for
    Finite-Difference), as:
    
     1) it is more descriptive, and
     2) the current name prevents numpy from being imported when in the
        /gpaw folder, and __main__ methods in any file in the /gpaw folder
        from being executed, as numpy has a relative import
        of a module called operators.py!

    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6824 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6205 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Resolve strange import of non-working FermiDiracFixed in parallel/ut_invops. WFS now require an additional nvalence argument (totalling 14 non-keyword arguments!)
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5320 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Changed setup.O_ii -> dO_ii and setup.C_ii -> dC_ii for consistency with their definitions (Delta Something). Migrated this change to everything that references O_ii, but some still call it dS_ii because of the overlap operator S/O ambiguity. Updated doc as well. Closes #9 apart from S/O naming conventions
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5313 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Optimization for the PairOverlap operator family. Cleanup of left-over code which is now obsolete as ut_invops passes in all cases new/old lfc, serial/parallel. The exact inverse S operator is now ready for use.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4408 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix for calculation of projector-projector overlaps between atomic pairs for NewLFC in the parallel case (relevant atoms with overlap contributions are pt.atom_indices rather than pt.my_atom_indices). This makes the ut_invops parallel unittest pass in parallel mode, so I can safely conclude that the NewLFC add/integrate functions work just as well as OldLFC within a working precision of 1e-12!

    Optimized inverse overlap module for NewLFC using the newly implemented get_functions method in Spline. Strangely, the test case ut_invops shows that NewLFC gives small errors around 1e-6 when domain decomposition is in effect - more debugging to follow.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4382 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2049 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4262 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4221 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    many improvements to hgh.  Fixed issue with representation of atomic hamiltonian in hgh.  Extracted some more code from setup creation into distinct functions.  Disable hgh test while more changes are being made
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4130 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1917 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Correction for average electrostatic potential
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1915 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    I've now implemented the core eigenvalue calculation using Janak's theorem.
    Since I've derived the expressions for my Master's thesis with help of developers guide and
    https://wiki.fysik.dtu.dk/gpaw/Eigenvalues_of_core_states
    I can post more detailed documentation next week.
    
    It is based on GLLB--classes since I need the eigenvalues especially for GLLB
    calculations. For testing purposed I introduced a functional labeled GLLBLDARCR,
    which is exactly the LDA functional, but with core eigenvalues calculated.
    
    For general core eigenvalue calculation, post-scf-xas or so, I offer the programming task to somebody else,
    since I'm rather busy with this GLLB stuff, but it should be relatively easy. Currently the eigenvalues
    are calculated on every iteration, since I will use them to make GLLB self consistent with core response also.
    
    BTW, Do you know any good references for testing? I did a turbomole calculation
    for H2O and got a value of -18.60729Ha for lowest occupied orbital, and
    corresponding calculation with GPAW yielded -18.60716Ha for O1s.
    
    BR,
    Mikael

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1321 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Getting ready for multiple zeta basis-sets
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1318 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6527 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Change default value for nn from 'M' to 3.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6406 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@623 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@562 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restrictor and Interpolator objects have been replaced by one Translator object

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7460 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7459 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introducing a concept of 'Kohn-Sham layouts' which is to be responsible for parallel interplay between band and domain communicator layouts of the Kohn-Sham representation in both LCAO and FD mode. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hackerish fix to ut_hsblacs.py and BlacsBandMatrixDesciptor to have MatrixOperator return/accept a 2D layout instead of 1D column/row. Diagonalization and inverse cholesky works now.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6035 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Changed matrix desciptor to expect 1D row layout of input to matrix multiply. Added parallel test suite for BLACS aspects of hs_operators.py equivalent to what is being tested by ut_hsops.py for non-BLACS.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5814 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented a safer factorial and renamed pre-tabulated list to something that's easier search-able.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6832 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Rearrange code.  Stencils now inherit from FDOperator.

    Added a minor docstring explaining what transformers.py and operators.py actually do.
    
    operators.py should be renamed to fd_operatos.py (for
    Finite-Difference), as:
    
     1) it is more descriptive, and
     2) the current name prevents numpy from being imported when in the
        /gpaw folder, and __main__ methods in any file in the /gpaw folder
        from being executed, as numpy has a relative import
        of a module called operators.py!

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1345 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6826 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6824 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6355 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Treat the user a bit more gently

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4577 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bugfix which closes #121. This is what happens when you borrow someone else's stuff without asking. In eigensolvers/eigensolver.py the interim function H used the work arrays allocated by Operator in hs_operators.py, but the size didn't always match. In the case of ticket 121, this lead to a return value of shape (125,29,29,29) rather than the correct (120,29,29,29). Implemented a little function in hs_operators called suggest_temporary_buffer which should *always* be used outside of hs_operators (the RM-DIIS eigensolver still doesn't respect this). Also removed an obsolete argument to allocate/estimate_memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4397 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1971 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.

    Paw-constructor/set method accepts PoissonSolver objects in addition to strings.  The eigensolver(name) method has been renamed to get_eigensolver due to namespace conflict with module eigensolver.py.  Eigensolvers now have an lcao boolean which is False except for LCAO-type eigensolvers.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1351 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    More handles on setup generation:
    
    * Radius for comp. charges.
    * zero-potential cutoff radius.
    * zero-potential type: polynomial or f-local potential.
    * Fourier-filtering: target grid spacing and cutoff radius.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@682 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added a calculator keyword "fixmom" to do fixed spin moment calculations.
    In addition to integer occupations, FSM should work also with k-points
    and Fermi smearing.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@666 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Print out the excess charge when there is a problem with charge conservation
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@653 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Keyword 'old' has been removed.  The 'mix' keyword is now a tuple of three numbers:
    
    * the mixing coefficient
    * the number of old densities
    * parameter used for special metric.
    
    If the special metric parameter is x, then long wavelength changes are weighed x times higher than short wavelengths.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@557 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restrictor and Interpolator objects have been replaced by one Translator object
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@505 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restarting from a file with no wave functions triggered an immediate initialization of the wave functions from atomic ones.  This is now delayed to the time where the wave functions are actually needed.  The tar-file restart file format has been changed to use 32-bit integers for Int arrays.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@494 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    Improvements to the MPI module: Backported the improvements made to
    the Asap.mpi module since that module was copied from GPAW.
    
    1) Keyword arguments for optional arguments.
    
    2) More reduction operators, and more data types for the reduction operators.
    
    3) Sanity checks moved from Python to C, and also enabled when not in
    debug mode.

    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.

    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6208 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5608 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Don't use mpi.world in any of the GPAW modules because it may conflict with user-specified communicator arguments. Also, hs_operators shouldn't have world.barrier()'s because it must be possible to perform operations on only e.g kpoint masters (independent operations). I still can't see why we need barriers at all, but combined band_comm and domain_comm barriers should do basically the same as world barriers did.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4584 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed allocation of work arrays in hs_operators so that odd cases won't result in a ridiculous amount of wasted memory (just try nblocks=mynbands where gd.n_c.prod() % nblocks != 0). The integer logic is a bit involved, so added docstring to allocate in order to explain it. Thanks to Nichols for pointing this out.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4515 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bugfix which closes #121. This is what happens when you borrow someone else's stuff without asking. In eigensolvers/eigensolver.py the interim function H used the work arrays allocated by Operator in hs_operators.py, but the size didn't always match. In the case of ticket 121, this lead to a return value of shape (125,29,29,29) rather than the correct (120,29,29,29). Implemented a little function in hs_operators called suggest_temporary_buffer which should *always* be used outside of hs_operators (the RM-DIIS eigensolver still doesn't respect this). Also removed an obsolete argument to allocate/estimate_memory.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3991 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added doc and extended Operator class method calculate_matrix_elements in hs_operators to allow dynamically specified projector-projector coefficients for an operator (specifying static dA_aii remains unchanged). This is handy for calculating overlaps between different wavefunctions i.e. <psi_m|chi_n> by having the A function return chit_nG and the dA function return np.dot(Q_ni, setups[a].O_ii) where Q_ni=<pt_i|chit_n>.

    pawextra.py: Fixed a typo.
    ase.py: When eigenvalue is None, do not try to multiply it with a number.
    
    Now the following code will work:
    
    if mpi.world.rank == 0:
        all_eigs = []
    
    for k, kpt_c in enumerate(calc.GetIBZKPoints()):
        result = calc.GetEigenvalues(kpt=k)
        if mpi.world.rank == 0:
            for eig in result:
                all_eigs.append(eig - calc.GetFermiLevel())
    
    # Processor 0 will now have all eigenvalues in list all_eigs

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1119 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4892 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented a Python interface for easily transferring spherical splines in NewLFC-format to the part of a rectangular grid enclosed by a given box. This works pretty much the same was as the OldLFC-style LocalizedFunctions.get_functions, but solely using NewLFC-methods. Now it is rather easy to plot e.g. the projector functions by just transferring them to a small box on the grid!
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4381 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1092 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Small documentation fixes.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1057 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The first versions of apply_scalar_function in kpoint.py and apply_polynomial in nuclues.py.
    The function apply_scalar_function applies a scalar function f(x,y,z) to smooth_wavefunctions
    psit_n. The function f(x,y,z) is approximated by a low-order (currently, quadratic) polynomial
    operator inside each augmentation sphere. The polynomial is contructed by making a
    least-squares fit to points (0,0,0), 3/8 (r_cut,0,0), 3/4 (r_cut,r_cut,r_cut), and to points
    symmetric in cubic symmetry. The functions are required in applying external potential to
    smooth wavefunctions in TDDFT.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1054 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@536 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added some text describing parallelizing over k-points.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@535 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4247 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    HGH now uses AtomPAW to generate high-quality initial guess on the fly.  Improvements to the new grid descriptor classes and the Basis class.  Miscellaneous minor improvements mainly in HGH
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4221 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Extended parsize parameter and --domain-decomposition command line argument to allow a single int (usually tuple of 3 ints). This is especially usefull when trying to control the creation of communicators/distribution of cpus in a more general and less grid-specific sense. Running '$ mpirun -np 4 gpaw-python test.py --domain-decomposition=4' can be used to force all tests into parallel-over-domain-only scenarios, yet still adapting the parsize_c 3-tuple to fit the various grids (4x1x1 in some cases, 2x2x1 in others etc.), thus avoiding most grid-too-small errors.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4206 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Better test
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4199 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Raise a proper error if it is not allowed
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4195 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    In the wave function IO several sends are posted before the corresponding
    receives. This causes problems in some architectures (at least Cray XT)
    so it is better to use syncronous send (MPI_Ssend)

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@510 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@509 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed nasty parallel bug
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@506 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@496 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3687 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    new localized functions integrate "the wrong way", i.e.
    
    newlfc.integrate2(psi_nG, c_nM, q=q)
    
    stores in c_nM, the values
    
    c_nM = <Phi_M|psi_n>
    
    which is of coarse consistent with the weird definition
    
    P_ni = <pt_i|psi_n>
    
    but not what you would expect.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6833 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6115 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix the way hooks are run and add a 'crashed' hook
    
    This is my working .gpaw/rc.py, which commits both crashed and converged
    results to my local database:
    
    0rams={
        "keywords":["gpaw"],
        "description": "Automatic",
    }
    
    def converged(calc):
        params["keywords"].append("converged")
        calc.write(".db", cmr_params=params)
    
    def crashed(calc):
        params["keywords"].append("crashed")
        calc.write(".db", cmr_params=params)

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4214 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Extended parsize parameter and --domain-decomposition command line argument to allow a single int (usually tuple of 3 ints). This is especially usefull when trying to control the creation of communicators/distribution of cpus in a more general and less grid-specific sense. Running '$ mpirun -np 4 gpaw-python test.py --domain-decomposition=4' can be used to force all tests into parallel-over-domain-only scenarios, yet still adapting the parsize_c 3-tuple to fit the various grids (4x1x1 in some cases, 2x2x1 in others etc.), thus avoiding most grid-too-small errors.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4206 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Quick fix until somebody has time to fix it.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4013 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The txt file is now opened in line-buffered mode, so progress can
    better be monitored by watching the file.  The flush() commands in the
    code should remain in case somebody calls GPAW with an already opened
    file object that is fully buffered.
    
    A cleanup function is now registered with Python shutting down all MPI
    tasks if one of them fails with an exception.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1358 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Temporary fix for conflict between gpaw-pythons use of ACML and Numeric's use of ACML
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@873 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    makes the program exit before constructing the Paw object.
    In future, also the parallelizatin could be checked...

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4237 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6205 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6149 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1900 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1865 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1839 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    When slicing numpy arrays, there is a difference between tuple and list (=npy array) arguments. A tuple will pick out the indicated element as in Numeric, while a list (or 1D array) will return the indicated rows along the first dimension.
    
    Examples:
    *  array[(5, 10, 15)] will return the (5, 10, 15) element (equivalent to array[5,10,15] )
    *  array[:, [5, 8]] will return the 5'th and 8'th column (equivalent to array.take([5, 8], axis=1) )
    
    the feature is called "fancy indexing".
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1723 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@656 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Minor adjustments to the new Exx object, and an update of the atomization script
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@528 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    New LDAx functional (LDA exchange only).
    
    Moved exx stuff around.  Same EXX class is now used for both self-consistent and non self-consistent exx.  Self-consistent exx seems to work for all-electron calculations, but not quite for PAW.  Note also that it may not work in parallel mode.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@523 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restrictor and Interpolator objects have been replaced by one Translator object

    XCFunctional method get_xc_name() renamed to get_name().

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4704 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Extended parsize parameter and --domain-decomposition command line argument to allow a single int (usually tuple of 3 ints). This is especially usefull when trying to control the creation of communicators/distribution of cpus in a more general and less grid-specific sense. Running '$ mpirun -np 4 gpaw-python test.py --domain-decomposition=4' can be used to force all tests into parallel-over-domain-only scenarios, yet still adapting the parsize_c 3-tuple to fit the various grids (4x1x1 in some cases, 2x2x1 in others etc.), thus avoiding most grid-too-small errors.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4206 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Adding code for doing PAW calculations for spherically symmetric atoms using radial 1-d grids.  This is mainly for transferability tests of setups.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6819 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    The txt file is now opened in line-buffered mode, so progress can
    better be monitored by watching the file.  The flush() commands in the
    code should remain in case somebody calls GPAW with an already opened
    file object that is fully buffered.
    
    A cleanup function is now registered with Python shutting down all MPI
    tasks if one of them fails with an exception.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1358 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1138 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5847 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Updated hs_operators to include dummy calls to redistribute to/from A_qnn and 1D column layout in the BLACS case (does nothing in non-BLACS case). Swapped q1 and q2 indices in BandMatrixDescriptor.extract_block to comply with the convention of block assigns. New BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor fully support 1D column layout, but for now, redistributes further to/from 1D column layout and full matrix for testing purposes. Test suite parallel/ut_hsops.py passes for non-strided band groups when using BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor instead of BandMatrixDescriptor on line 42 of hs_operators.py

    A number of smaller tweaks to the BandDescriptor in relation to parallel matrix assignment.     git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4308 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4190 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added non-hermitian capability to Operator.calculate_matrix_elements in hs_operators. Rearranged code to avoid duplication of async/sync modes by introducing helper functions in the class - hopefully this has improven the readability for others (I think it did). Added comments and docstrings here and there. From testing, it seems that the sync mode works for an odd number of processors as well, but I suspect that there is a performance hit so I've disabled it for now.

Diagonalization works for both strided and blocked groups now.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4241 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    HGH now uses AtomPAW to generate high-quality initial guess on the fly.  Improvements to the new grid descriptor classes and the Basis class.  Miscellaneous minor improvements mainly in HGH
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4221 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.

    DeprecationWarning for md5 in Python 2.6 avoided.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Cleanup of code for MD5 fingerprinting arrays. Adding two random ints often causes wrap-around - it's cleaner to use bitwise XOR to reduce 128 bits to 64 bits. Also, there is no exact floating point rounding so removed the feature and added a warning about comparing MD5 fingerprints of rounded arrays with nearly-idendical data.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4100 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Converting MD5 sum to a complex number can produce nan's.  Use integers instead.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1839 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Warning on the use of a.conj() versus npy.conj(a)
    
    If a is real, a.conj() returns a pointer to the original array.
    If this is *not* desired, use npy.conj(a) which will always make a copy.
    
    The problem arises if you try to do something like a += a.T.conj(), which will not produce an error, but will give the wrong result, as the thing you add is a view into the array you a modifying.
    
    Nasty
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1823 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

      >> array([0,1,1]) and array([1,1,1])
    gives the result
      >> array([1,1,1])

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6992 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6355 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Seperated out old ScaLAPACK and serial LAPACK debug interface. Unfortunately, not very pretty. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK in LCAO code, since this is not needed with the new BLAC. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK's inverse cholesky in real-space code to make way for new BLACS code. Also, sl_inverse_cholesky rarely got used as serial Cholesky is fine up to N=3500. Implemented simultaneous: spin, band, and domain parallelization in real-space code using old ScaLAPACK.

    find existing way to do that for a simple function argument, e.g.
    def f(a):
      b = ...
      a, b = b, a # does not work, creates a new variable a
      swap(a,b) # does the job

    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5099 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    This was a very subtle bug introduced when scalapack_redist was generalized to allow the complex type. When matrices are redistributed between different blacs grids, we do not require that the matrices exist on the union of the blacs processor grids. In other words, we permit the None type on processors in the blacs grid which do not contain the source matrix. None does not contain a dtype of real or complex; but we need all the processors in the blacs grid to either call the real or complex redist function. This is neatest workaround possible. Another possible was to force the creation of empty arrays outside the blacs grid, this is even more confusing and wastes memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4758 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Some fixes

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1345 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Keyword 'old' has been removed.  The 'mix' keyword is now a tuple of three numbers:
    
    * the mixing coefficient
    * the number of old densities
    * parameter used for special metric.
    
    If the special metric parameter is x, then long wavelength changes are weighed x times higher than short wavelengths.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@557 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@454 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@449 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
