    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6527 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Change default value for nn from 'M' to 3.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6406 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@623 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Updated some notation and removed superfluous imports in generator.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@562 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restrictor and Interpolator objects have been replaced by one Translator object
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@505 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.

    Poisson solver gets the tolerance of the potential as input parameter (possibility to change tolerance during SCF-iterations)

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@140 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default Poisson solver uses now the Jacobi iteration for smoothing
    the solution in all multigrid levels
    
    Add a new keyword maxiter for the calculater which determines the
    maximum number of iterations to do
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@120 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented Gauss-Seidel relaxations for the Poisson multigrid solver
    In class PoissonSolver there is now new subroutine iterate2, which
    performs couple of Gauss-Seidel iterations in all multigrid levels.
    As the new subroutine has not been thoroughly tested, the old subroutine
    iterate is still the default.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6676 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    More sane conversion between grid spacing and number of grid points for non-orthorhombic cells.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6261 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@861 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    New io module added.   All the nasty NetCDF details are now hidden in gridpaw/io/netcdf.py and there is an alternative simple tar-file format implemented in gridpaw/io/tar.py.  This means that we can now use gpaw without having netCDF and Scientific installed.

    Initial work on the Allow-tests-to-be-run-in-parallel project.  The goal is that the tests sould run on at least 2 and 4 cores.
    
    Another long-term goal is to move the test directory from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test (like for ASE) so that the tests are always available.  Like for ASE, one should do "cd /tmp; gpaw-test.py" to run the tests, and the tests should not be required to clean up files.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6749 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Specify explicitly the number of grid points so that rounding errors
    do not give inconsistent grids in different compiler, blas etc. environments
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6393 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7223 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Solved the problem where instances of classes defined in test scripts would lead to uncollectable garbage. The empty globals/locals dict passed to execfile must be cleared before we check the garbage collector because, while it goes out of scope immediately after the call to execfile, there's no guarantee that it is garbage collected in the right order during the gc.collect invokation.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7006 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6393 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6515 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Specify explicitly the number of grid points so that rounding errors
    do not give inconsistent grids in different compiler, blas etc. environments
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6393 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4546 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    On my machine, convergence goes as this
    
    iter:  22  08:06:34  -8.5   -5.6     -12.02748    1      1
    iter:  23  08:06:37  -9.0   -5.6     -12.02749    1      1
    iter:  24  08:06:40  -7.8   -5.4     -12.02746    1      1
    iter:  25  08:06:43  -9.5   -6.0     -12.02747    1      1
    ------------------------------------
    Converged After 25 Iterations.
    
    But as the error is -9.0 at iteration 23, some machines might converge
    at this point, provoking a test failure (I guess, since the nightly
    test-suite fails on casimir!).
    
    Issue fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4545 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Add Si with primitive unit cell to test suite.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4479 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added test for Si with primitive (nonorthorhombic) unit cell.
    The test can not be run as part of the test-suite, as setting --gpaw usenewlfc=True does not work in this case.
    
    Ps. If you use a nonorthorhombic cell and forget to set usenewlfc=True, the code will not complain, but will never converge.
    
    It should produce an error!

    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup

    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6749 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6736 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Allowed 'bands' convergence criterion to be a negative integer.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1184 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    calculation with higher accuracy

    fixed imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6730 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Specify explicitly the number of grid points so that rounding errors
    do not give inconsistent grids in different compiler, blas etc. environments
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6393 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3172 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Initial work on the Allow-tests-to-be-run-in-parallel project.  The goal is that the tests sould run on at least 2 and 4 cores.
    
    Another long-term goal is to move the test directory from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test (like for ASE) so that the tests are always available.  Like for ASE, one should do "cd /tmp; gpaw-test.py" to run the tests, and the tests should not be required to clean up files.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    exx_PBE0.py and exx.py combined; tests are based on results from 1170 version
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1172 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    libxc functionals used by default for LDA, PBE, revPBE, and PBE0; XCFunctional(xcname).get_name() has to be used to get the full libxc name wherever possible
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1155 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@131 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6687 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5059 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Moving test suite from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5020 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bug fix: the test suite would occationally hang when running in
    parallel.  The previous fix did not fully solve the problem.
    
    When a parallel test sequentially writes and reads a file, and REUSE
    THE SAME FILE NAME, a barrier call must be made not just after each
    write, but also before the next write.  Otherwise the master process
    may overwrite the file with the next test, before one of the other
    tasks has completed reading it.
    
    Closes #87.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3608 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    sleep only in parallel case - saves execution time for serial tests
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3602 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Insert sleep(2) statements after selected barrier statements, to
    minimize race conditions when running parallel test suite, see ticket
    #87.
    
    This does not fix bug #87, but minimizes its impact.

    Initial work on the Allow-tests-to-be-run-in-parallel project.  The goal is that the tests sould run on at least 2 and 4 cores.
    
    Another long-term goal is to move the test directory from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test (like for ASE) so that the tests are always available.  Like for ASE, one should do "cd /tmp; gpaw-test.py" to run the tests, and the tests should not be required to clean up files.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6765 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6749 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4340 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4089 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    transformers, xc3dgrid, hamiltonian and density objects now require more or less explicit allocate() calls.  This makes things a bit more complicated, but will reduce dry-run memory use considerably, and things can be simplified later if we adhere more to this scheme.  Transformer wrapping classes made more logical.  Memory estimate improved.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3688 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    No need to parallelize this test.

    Make GridDescriptor object more user friendly:  Don't require a Domain object and let default domain communicator be mpi.world.  GridDescriptor now inherits from Domain, so use gd.cell_cv instead of gd.domain.cell_cv and so on ...

    Checking in everything
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    fixed imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6712 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    tests relaxed

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3172 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.     Fix imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6736 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Add missing zero to two-center integral spline and downsample.  Also adjusted LCAO tests.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4114 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Final touches on parallel unit test module. Give aliases to remaining unittest classes of the serial variants and allow import of these through the parunittest module. Also, the original unittest module (in the Python standard library) has a copyright message/disclaimer which must be included in derived works - better safe than sorry.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4111 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major overhaul of parallel unit test module. Restructured a bit to maintain a cleaner parallel version of TextTestRunner. Implemented grouping of ranks with identical error/failure messages to avoid flooding output stream on massively parallel runs. Major improvement of backwards compatibility, which is complicated by the last 5 years (!) of ongoing development on the Unittest module from Python 2.3 to 2.6. Module has been tested with version 1.46 r34135 through 1.63 r66716 and works - I have yet to write a unit test module to test the unit test module *sigh*.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4110 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented parallel version of the unittest module. If a test fails on just one CPU, the entire test is a failure and the stacktrace gets broadcasted. This way, we'll know e.g. if the kpt_comm slaves raises errors even though we're only logging output from the world master. For optimal use, use devnull as output stream on world slaves (test suite will produce the same output on all ranks).

    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup

    Another long-term goal is to move the test directory from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test (like for ASE) so that the tests are always available.  Like for ASE, one should do "cd /tmp; gpaw-test.py" to run the tests, and the tests should not be required to clean up files.

    Test too strict.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6130 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1922 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The new logic in the PAW.set() method does not work as before for set(eigensolver='...'), so the cg.py and davidson.py tests were not actually testing the CG and Davidson algorithms anymore!
    
    This kind of problem is hard to detect.  In the future, we should maybe time each test - then an alarm could go off if a test suddently becomes much faster.

    diagonalize_mr3 is always faster than diagonalize by up to a factor of two. If dtype=float, mr3 maybe even be faster than the parallel counter part for up to N=800. If dtype=complex, the cross-over point will be lower ~ N=600. Also committed a small regression test which is not currently enabled

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@490 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@449 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Allow to restart from a converged density and change the number of wave functions.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5505 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6709 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4340 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7641 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed Density.initialize_from_wavefunctions to actually do what the docstring says it does i.e. also initialize and calculate D_asp. Note that this closes a tiny bug where the old D_asp would be reused in the first SCF step e.g. after a call to PAW.set would trigger reconstruction of nt_sG (but not D_asp) from wavefunctions or some such nonsense. On another note, the energy tolerances in the revPBE.py and nonselfconsistent.py tests are ridiculously stict compared to the convergence criteria.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7411 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    fix import * stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6683 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Fix imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6736 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6687 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    HGH now uses AtomPAW to generate high-quality initial guess on the fly.  Improvements to the new grid descriptor classes and the Basis class.  Miscellaneous minor improvements mainly in HGH
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4221 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Making NewLFC exactly similar to OldLFC.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4197 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    extracted some of the code from Setup constructor to separate methods, in order to allow overriding (some of this is rather messy still).  Removed some broken and unused code in Setup (reference to AESetup and smooth compensation charges).  Made changes such that one can specify a SetupData object through the setups kwarg of GPAW, which is less convoluted than creating proper Setup objects.  Some methods moved from Setup to SetupData, which means HGH setups can override those methods more flexibly.  HGH class changed to subclass of SetupData.  Setup constructor parameters are slightly changed, so tests now generally invoke create_setup
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4089 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7128 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Solved the problem where instances of classes defined in test scripts would lead to uncollectable garbage. The empty globals/locals dict passed to execfile must be cleared before we check the garbage collector because, while it goes out of scope immediately after the call to execfile, there's no guarantee that it is garbage collected in the right order during the gc.collect invokation.

    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6125 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Implement C backend to MPI_Testall, update Python interface and add a missing return. Added an interim MPI_Ibarrier-like function which can work both as a non-blocking barrier and a blocking barrier with a time-out limit. Closes #156 by using the blocking barrier in the test suite with a time-limit of 1 minute, after which the test suite indirectly invokes an MPI_Abort.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6779 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6749 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7420 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6687 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix timing for relax.py test by exclusively measuring the time it takes to calculate/retrieve the forces. This test caused problems when running the test suite in coverage-mode with 8 threads on 2 cores because of the asserts that each operation took less than 0.5 seconds, sometimes causing individual threads to fail.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7306 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5059 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Moving test suite from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5020 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bug fix: the test suite would occationally hang when running in
    parallel.  The previous fix did not fully solve the problem.
    
    When a parallel test sequentially writes and reads a file, and REUSE
    THE SAME FILE NAME, a barrier call must be made not just after each
    write, but also before the next write.  Otherwise the master process
    may overwrite the file with the next test, before one of the other
    tasks has completed reading it.
    
    Closes #87.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3608 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    sleep only in parallel case - saves execution time for serial tests
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3602 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Insert sleep(2) statements after selected barrier statements, to
    minimize race conditions when running parallel test suite, see ticket
    #87.
    
    This does not fix bug #87, but minimizes its impact.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3601 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Always check gpw format and only nc format if Scientific.IO.NetCDF is there
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1226 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    Test for speed of dgemm.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2772 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    fixed imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6711 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6533 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    correct usesymm=None error & update EELS test
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6380 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7412 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed Density.initialize_from_wavefunctions to actually do what the docstring says it does i.e. also initialize and calculate D_asp. Note that this closes a tiny bug where the old D_asp would be reused in the first SCF step e.g. after a call to PAW.set would trigger reconstruction of nt_sG (but not D_asp) from wavefunctions or some such nonsense. On another note, the energy tolerances in the revPBE.py and nonselfconsistent.py tests are ridiculously stict compared to the convergence criteria.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7411 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    fixed imports
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6681 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1922 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The new logic in the PAW.set() method does not work as before for set(eigensolver='...'), so the cg.py and davidson.py tests were not actually testing the CG and Davidson algorithms anymore!
    
    This kind of problem is hard to detect.  In the future, we should maybe time each test - then an alarm could go off if a test suddently becomes much faster.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6556 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    - introducing queueopts argument that allows one to specify
    any qsub options (as a string). This allows one to
    run the job on opterons, for example.
    - if ncpus is 1 - gpaw-python is run now without mpiexec.
    This allows one to start mpi inside a python script for example.
    - adding -V option (export all environment variables) to qsub.
    - modified examples of selecting jobs

    Test too strict.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6141 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6237 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6237 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6731 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Move some of the slow tests from the old test suite to the new weekly-test system.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6237 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    tests relaxed

    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    Test too strict.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6128 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    That was too easy ...

    Merging xc-branch to trunk.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7223 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix import stuff
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6749 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Remove use of width and fixmom keywords.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5333 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Use gpaw.test.gen() function to generate setups at test-time. Closes #62

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7498 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    More regression tests that I missed.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7391 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Reorganization of BLACS. Inserted copyright statements for ANL and CAMD as appropriate.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7386 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Pretty sure these should have been asserts all along.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6092 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introducing a concept of 'Kohn-Sham layouts' which is to be responsible for parallel interplay between band and domain communicator layouts of the Kohn-Sham representation in both LCAO and FD mode. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The parallel/realspace_blacs.py test was mistakenly never run (excluded if world.size != 4 or world.size != 8, which is always true).

    Ups, forgot to include parallel/realspace_blacs.py in r5928

    ScaLAPACK inverse_cholesky zeroes the opposite diagonal by default, rather than relying on the trapezoidal redistribute function. This simplies the SLDenseLinearAlgebra class as well. Updated regression tests and some other minor fixes.

    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    forgot to delete this

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6729 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6569 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6355 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    svnrevision renamed to svnversion
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6124 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Fix for calculation of projector-projector overlaps between atomic pairs for NewLFC in the parallel case (relevant atoms with overlap contributions are pt.atom_indices rather than pt.my_atom_indices). This makes the ut_invops parallel unittest pass in parallel mode, so I can safely conclude that the NewLFC add/integrate functions work just as well as OldLFC within a working precision of 1e-12!
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4407 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Updated module for exact inverse Overlap operator S to support NewLFC as well as old. NewLFC-use hasn't been optimized yet so it's several orders of magnitude slower that using old LFC for this.     git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7223 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Revert BLACS changes of hs_operators to r5608 (ish) and move pseudo-code to a seperate class. Renamed Operator in hs_operators to MatrixOperator in order to avoid confusion with Operator in fd_operators. Cleanup of unused variables too.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6652 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Specify explicitly the number of grid points so that rounding errors

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6393 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default poisson solver is now PoissonSolver(nn=3, relax='J').  You can get the old one by using PoissonSolver(nn='M'), which will not work for non-orthogonal cells.
    
    The default value for the relax keyword of the PoissonSolver class has been changed from 'GS' to 'J' (Gauss-Seidel to Jacobi).
    
    For non-orthogonal cells, the more new efficient and sparse fd-stencil is now used.  Use --gpaw=newgucstencil=False to get the old stencil.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6121 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5020 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    This was a very subtle bug introduced when scalapack_redist was generalized to allow the complex type. When matrices are redistributed between different blacs grids, we do not require that the matrices exist on the union of the blacs processor grids. In other words, we permit the None type on processors in the blacs grid which do not contain the source matrix. None does not contain a dtype of real or complex; but we need all the processors in the blacs grid to either call the real or complex redist function. This is neatest workaround possible. Another possible was to force the creation of empty arrays outside the blacs grid, this is even more confusing and wastes memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4758 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    trivial fix
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4194 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    setups are now created the 'right' way - SetupData instances define a build() method which, given certain arguments, constructs a legit Setup object.  The setup module now defines a LeanSetup class which contains the minimal necessary attribute set, such that one won't have to implement *all* the stuff defined by the ordinary Setup class.  HGH setups no longer inherit from PAW setups, and now define only the required attributes; also removed a multitude of ugly hacks, so HGH setups don't deal with nonsensical things like AE core density.  HGH setups can now choose their own spline cutoffs rather than relying on Setup to do this wisely (which it didn't).  Improved the radial grid descriptors to create splines more transparently.  Sorry about the size of this commit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4185 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    New Br setup based on reference data from http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.1574317;
    reference dipole moment for I-Br ignored because does not look converged
      X-Y| r [A]|   ref|   [%]| w [1/cm]|    ref|   [%]| m [D]|   ref|   [%]|
    Br-Br| 2.352| 2.352|   0.0|    294.0|  290.0|   1.4| 0.000| 0.000|   0.0|
    Br-Cl| 2.203| 2.205|  -0.1|    397.2|  395.3|   0.5| 0.546| 0.576|  -5.3|
     Br-F| 1.820| 1.813|   0.4|    622.0|  612.8|   1.5| 1.483| 1.483|  -0.0|
     H-Br| 1.438| 1.436|   0.1|   2532.0| 2512.9|   0.8| 0.754| 0.750|   0.5|
     I-Br| 2.540| 2.555|  -0.6|    245.9|  233.3|   5.4| 0.000| 0.000|   0.0|
    
    Results obtained with:
    scripts/XY.py -v --mode=calculate --spacings="\[0.14\]" Br

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1860 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    I've now implemented the core eigenvalue calculation using Janak's theorem.
    Since I've derived the expressions for my Master's thesis with help of developers guide and
    https://wiki.fysik.dtu.dk/gpaw/Eigenvalues_of_core_states
    I can post more detailed documentation next week.
    
    It is based on GLLB--classes since I need the eigenvalues especially for GLLB
    calculations. For testing purposed I introduced a functional labeled GLLBLDARCR,
    which is exactly the LDA functional, but with core eigenvalues calculated.
    
    For general core eigenvalue calculation, post-scf-xas or so, I offer the programming task to somebody else,
    since I'm rather busy with this GLLB stuff, but it should be relatively easy. Currently the eigenvalues
    are calculated on every iteration, since I will use them to make GLLB self consistent with core response also.
    
    BTW, Do you know any good references for testing? I did a turbomole calculation
    for H2O and got a value of -18.60729Ha for lowest occupied orbital, and
    corresponding calculation with GPAW yielded -18.60716Ha for O1s.
    
    BR,
    Mikael

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1251 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1229 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    GLLB _might_ now work in 3D also. I haven't tested it but just for three atoms. The forces have to be thinked
    through at some point, since GLLB potential is not a functional derivative of any Exchange Energy Functional.
    
    On Tue, 9 Oct 2007, Jens Jørgen Mortensen wrote:
    
    > On Mon, 2007-10-08 at 12:56 +0300, mikael.kuisma wrote:
    >> -I tried using just the smooth valence wave functions, which resulted ghost
    >> states, and no setups could be created.
    >
    > I would also use pseudo valence-orbitals (no pseudo core-states) and
    > pseudo electron densities - so for the response potential, the sum
    > should be over valence orbitals only.  If this potential gives
    > ghost-states, then you can try to play with the cutoff radii and vbar -
    > maybe that can help.
    
    Excellent suggestion! I mean it works, exactly as you suggested.:)
    
    Here are the new data for spherical symmetric atoms, also 3D now included:
    
                 Quanity        Method    Symbol     Ref[1]         GPAW      Unit
            Total energy         1D         Be      -14.560      -14.561      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Be       -2.676       -2.676      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Be       -0.301       -0.301      Ha
            Total energy         1D         Ne     -128.577     -128.573      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Ne      -12.229      -12.229      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Ne       -0.753       -0.753      Ha
            Total energy         1D         Mg     -199.617     -199.615      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Mg      -16.084      -16.085      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Mg       -0.247       -0.247      Ha
      Total energy diff.         3D         Be        0.000        0.001      Ha
         Homo eigenvalue         3D         Be       -0.301       -0.300      Ha
      Total energy diff.         3D         Ne        0.000       -0.025      Ha
         Homo eigenvalue         3D         Ne       -0.753       -0.756      Ha
      Total energy diff.         3D         Mg        0.000        0.007      Ha
         Homo eigenvalue         3D         Mg       -0.247       -0.244      Ha
    References:
    [1] Self-consistent approximation to the Kohn-Sham exchange potential
    Gritsenko, Oleg; Leeuwen, Robert van; Lenthe, Erik van; Baerends, Evert Jan
    Phys. Rev. A Vol. 51 p. 1944
    
    One more thing. How can this code result such an
    output?
    
    >>> if 1:
    ...     for a in ['1','2','3']:
    ...             print a
    ...     else:
    ...             print "AARRCHH"
    ...
    1
    2
    3
    AARRCHH
    
    I would expect a syntax error. A bug in python?

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1174 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    A new way of generating the vXCt for non-local (GLLB) functionals. At least results no ghost states and a reasonably
    smooth potential compared to old version. ALL the all-electron orbitals are converted to smooth wave-functions and
    passed on to contruction of non-local vXCt.
    
    Hmm... Will the pseudo core density be equal to density constructed from
    these core pseudo wave-functions? Probably not, but will it matter, I will have to think about it.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1228 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The correct GGA-functional is now used for GLLB (thanks, Dulak), thus the reference values are within reasonable
    agreenment with the orginal article (see test/gllb2.py and the table below)
    
                 Quanity        Method    Symbol     Ref[1]         GPAW      Unit
            Total energy         1D         Be      -14.560      -14.561      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Be       -2.676       -2.676      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Be       -0.301       -0.301      Ha
            Total energy         1D         Ne     -128.577     -128.573      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Ne      -12.229      -12.229      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Ne       -0.753       -0.753      Ha
            Total energy         1D         Mg     -199.617     -199.615      Ha
         Exchange energy         1D         Mg      -16.084      -16.085      Ha
         HOMO Eigenvalue         1D         Mg       -0.247       -0.247      Ha
    References:
    [1] Self-consistent approximation to the Kohn-Sham exchange potential
    Gritsenko, Oleg; Leeuwen, Robert van; Lenthe, Erik van; Baerends, Evert Jan
    Phys. Rev. A Vol. 51 p. 1944
    
    In GLLB, the B88-exchange energy is used, thus I had to comment out following
    lines from all_electron.py
    
            # When iterations are over calculate the correct exchange energy
            #if self.xc.is_non_local():
            #    Exc = atomic_exact_exchange(self)
    
    This won't interfere with EXX, since the EXX-setups are not calculated
    with -f EXX, but with some other functional, correct? If I'm wrong please
    roll back this change.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@878 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added support for non-local exchange functionals in setup-generator.
    
    I have not checked the GLLB numerically yet, since there I use
    "revPBEx" and they used "Becke88" energy density. This script will
    plot the vxc for Xe. The agreement is excellent far from nucleus,
    but gga will fail close to nucleus.
    
    First impression is that, maybe it isn't so bad running GLLB calculations with KLI-setups.
    
    from all_electron import AllElectron
    import pylab
    
    KLI = AllElectron('Xe',xcname = 'KLI', scalarrel=True)
    GLLB =  AllElectron('Xe',xcname = 'GLLB', scalarrel=True)
    KLI.run()
    GLLB.run()
    
    pylab.plot(KLI.vXC)
    pylab.plot(GLLB.vXC)
    pylab.show()

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@596 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added 1D-AE-KLI which works for small atoms with fully occupied subshells.
    I think it also works (up to the spherically averaged potential) for
    atoms with partially filled shells, but you cannot compare the results
    to real atoms since, the all_electron.py does it's calculation is with
    fractional occupation numbers and spin-symmetrically.
    
    Is this enough for calculating setup's? The asymptiotical behaviour of
    KLI is -f_{HOMO}/r, (in B for example -0.16666/r) so it will create an
    error to at least the highest occupied orbital eigenvalues, '
    but maybe this isn't so important since the these orbitals are not used anyway.
    
    At some point, for example with Zn, the calcalation fails.
    Maybe this is due to the missing gaunt's coefficients that I am
    assuming to be zero.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3820 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    move analyse-basis to tools directory.  Basis plotting function improved and moved to basis_data, can now be used at runtime.  Adjusted default basis parameters.  Energy shift default is now 0.1 rather than 0.3, and dz-tail norms are now taken as arguments and written properly instead of their squares (values adjusted slightly).  Tests updated so as not to break because of this

    Prvent evil hackers from using global namespace.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4066 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Improved the TarFileReference class:
    
    1) Added an __iter__ method, so you can now loop over the elements.
       Before it would iterate beyond len(self)
    
    2) Added some "raise NotImplementedError" if you try indexing by
       a) tuples, e.g. array[1, 2, :] or something like that
       b) slices different from array[:] or array[::]
       Before, these cases would not cause an error, and something
       unexpected would happen
    
    Maybe a "raise KeyError" is more appropriate in 2)? My choice is
    motivated by the idea that I think it should be possible, but is just
    missing an implementation.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3966 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@895 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Restarting from a file with no wave functions triggered an immediate initialization of the wave functions from atomic ones.  This is now delayed to the time where the wave functions are actually needed.  The tar-file restart file format has been changed to use 32-bit integers for Int arrays.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@494 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now an error to restart from a file using setups that are different from those used to generate the restart file.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@412 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Renaming gridpaw to gpaw

    New io module added.   All the nasty NetCDF details are now hidden in gridpaw/io/netcdf.py and there is an alternative simple tar-file format implemented in gridpaw/io/tar.py.  This means that we can now use gpaw without having netCDF and Scientific installed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3781 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added extension to tarfile read/write support. Makes it possible to incrementally add data to multiple entries in each iteration by partitioning the binary data. Read/write using the get/add functions works the same as before, incremental writes simply use the partition/next functions.

    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1343 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Merging new-interface branch (667:957) to trunk
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1358 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1131 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@657 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The change suggested by JJ fixes now the problem of parallel IO with zero
