    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@642 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Keyword 'old' has been removed.  The 'mix' keyword is now a tuple of three numbers:
    
    * the mixing coefficient
    * the number of old densities
    * parameter used for special metric.
    
    If the special metric parameter is x, then long wavelength changes are weighed x times higher than short wavelengths.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@557 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    New LDAx functional (LDA exchange only).
    
    Moved exx stuff around.  Same EXX class is now used for both self-consistent and non self-consistent exx.  Self-consistent exx seems to work for all-electron calculations, but not quite for PAW.  Note also that it may not work in parallel mode.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@523 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4662 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Updates to xc_correction.py:
    
    * Lebedev point index is now (more) consistently called n (Y_yL -> Y_nL)
    * No special case for lmax==0 => global weights is used instead of self.weights
    * renamed np to nii and nq -> njj. It should now we trivial to do npy -> np
    * removed the nca_g and ncb_g attributes. Now only nc_g (and ncorehole_g) is used in NewXCCorrection
    * Simplified expand_density and expand_pseudo_density to one method + removed redundant work related to this.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4438 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4438 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    transformers, xc3dgrid, hamiltonian and density objects now require more or less explicit allocate() calls.  This makes things a bit more complicated, but will reduce dry-run memory use considerably, and things can be simplified later if we adhere more to this scheme.  Transformer wrapping classes made more logical.  Memory estimate improved.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Parallelization over k-point now supported for GLLB.
    
    For GLLB calculation of Silicon it has following results:
    Parallelization Over k-points on 4 Processors
    49.250s
    
    Single processor:
    116.027s
    
    Meaning only speedup of factor 2.3559.
    
    Next, I will take the O(N^3) scaling atomic density-matrix generation out of inner loop (meaning 50-fold less
    communication, and calculation) to see what will happend.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1302 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Malformed reStructuredText fixed
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1266 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1251 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1632 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    I rewrote the GLLB code. Hopefully this time it's free of bugs.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1631 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    -Renamed fermi_level to reference_level
    -Few comments added
    -Added possibility to add correlation to GLLB (P86)
    -Added possibility to use LUMO as a reference level instead of HOMO
    -Added possibility to "relax the core response" to new fermilevel (instead of using the one
    from setup-generator). Core orbitals and eigenvalues are still kept fixed in spirit
    of frozen core approximation.
    
    I am working on a larger test suite to test all this, it is probably the best
    that I won't add it to the standard test suite.
    
    Intresting thing I discovered:
    For accurate atom HOMO eigenvalues, GLLB requires much larger cell (12Å)
    compared to LDA, since LDA orbitals are more localized due to
    exponential decay of exchange potential. The 3D eigenvalues in test/gllb2.py
    will start to match better to 1D code if you do it with grid-spacing 0.18 and 12Å cell.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1350 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Malformed reStructuredText fixed
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1266 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3172 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    I've now implemented the core eigenvalue calculation using Janak's theorem.
    Since I've derived the expressions for my Master's thesis with help of developers guide and
    https://wiki.fysik.dtu.dk/gpaw/Eigenvalues_of_core_states
    I can post more detailed documentation next week.
    
    It is based on GLLB--classes since I need the eigenvalues especially for GLLB
    calculations. For testing purposed I introduced a functional labeled GLLBLDARCR,
    which is exactly the LDA functional, but with core eigenvalues calculated.
    
    For general core eigenvalue calculation, post-scf-xas or so, I offer the programming task to somebody else,
    since I'm rather busy with this GLLB stuff, but it should be relatively easy. Currently the eigenvalues
    are calculated on every iteration, since I will use them to make GLLB self consistent with core response also.
    
    BTW, Do you know any good references for testing? I did a turbomole calculation
    for H2O and got a value of -18.60729Ha for lowest occupied orbital, and
    corresponding calculation with GPAW yielded -18.60716Ha for O1s.
    
    BR,
    Mikael
    
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1859 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1632 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed epydoc errors - and cut lines down to max 79 characters
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1394 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    -Renamed fermi_level to reference_level
    -Few comments added
    -Added possibility to add correlation to GLLB (P86)
    -Added possibility to use LUMO as a reference level instead of HOMO
    -Added possibility to "relax the core response" to new fermilevel (instead of using the one
    from setup-generator). Core orbitals and eigenvalues are still kept fixed in spirit
    of frozen core approximation.
    
    I am working on a larger test suite to test all this, it is probably the best
    that I won't add it to the standard test suite.
    
    Intresting thing I discovered:
    For accurate atom HOMO eigenvalues, GLLB requires much larger cell (12Å)
    compared to LDA, since LDA orbitals are more localized due to
    exponential decay of exchange potential. The 3D eigenvalues in test/gllb2.py
    will start to match better to 1D code if you do it with grid-spacing 0.18 and 12Å cell.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1350 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixing bad reStructuredText
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1331 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Parallelization over k-point now supported for GLLB.
    
    For GLLB calculation of Silicon it has following results:
    Parallelization Over k-points on 4 Processors
    49.250s
    
    Single processor:
    116.027s
    
    Meaning only speedup of factor 2.3559.
    
    Next, I will take the O(N^3) scaling atomic density-matrix generation out of inner loop (meaning 50-fold less
    communication, and calculation) to see what will happend.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1302 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Malformed reStructuredText fixed
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1266 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4071 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    transformers, xc3dgrid, hamiltonian and density objects now require more or less explicit allocate() calls.  This makes things a bit more complicated, but will reduce dry-run memory use considerably, and things can be simplified later if we adhere more to this scheme.  Transformer wrapping classes made more logical.  Memory estimate improved.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@473 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6824 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6198 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6149 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Seperated out old ScaLAPACK and serial LAPACK debug interface. Unfortunately, not very pretty. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK in LCAO code, since this is not needed with the new BLAC. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK's inverse cholesky in real-space code to make way for new BLACS code. Also, sl_inverse_cholesky rarely got used as serial Cholesky is fine up to N=3500. Implemented simultaneous: spin, band, and domain parallelization in real-space code using old ScaLAPACK.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5999 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4437 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bugfix which closes #121. This is what happens when you borrow someone else's stuff without asking. In eigensolvers/eigensolver.py the interim function H used the work arrays allocated by Operator in hs_operators.py, but the size didn't always match. In the case of ticket 121, this lead to a return value of shape (125,29,29,29) rather than the correct (120,29,29,29). Implemented a little function in hs_operators called suggest_temporary_buffer which should *always* be used outside of hs_operators (the RM-DIIS eigensolver still doesn't respect this). Also removed an obsolete argument to allocate/estimate_memory.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1901 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1253 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@639 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Changed some notation on how to handle non-local xc-operators, and made a seperation of occupied/unoccupied states in the Hamiltonian matrix for the EXX functional.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@636 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed a few bugs for EXX calculations
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@615 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added Davidson eigensolver (keyword eigensolver="dav") and restructured
    the other eigensolvers a little bit
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@592 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    New LDAx functional (LDA exchange only).
    
    Moved exx stuff around.  Same EXX class is now used for both self-consistent and non self-consistent exx.  Self-consistent exx seems to work for all-electron calculations, but not quite for PAW.  Note also that it may not work in parallel mode.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@523 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@496 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Increased Gaunt coeff to support up to l=3 (f-states), and adjusted the exx hacks to accommodate the Hamiltonain and Eigensolver objects
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@459 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Conjugate gradient eigensolver
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@455 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@449 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Improve the timing of RMM-DIIS
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5400 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Minor syntax and docstring issues
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4658 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bugfix which closes #121. This is what happens when you borrow someone else's stuff without asking. In eigensolvers/eigensolver.py the interim function H used the work arrays allocated by Operator in hs_operators.py, but the size didn't always match. In the case of ticket 121, this lead to a return value of shape (125,29,29,29) rather than the correct (120,29,29,29). Implemented a little function in hs_operators called suggest_temporary_buffer which should *always* be used outside of hs_operators (the RM-DIIS eigensolver still doesn't respect this). Also removed an obsolete argument to allocate/estimate_memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4397 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Some changes for blocked preconditioner
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4212 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed bugs in state parallelization related to mixed blocked/strided grouping of bands. Implemented BandDescriptor to encompass both types of state parallelization, but always use blocked grouping by default.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1971 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1865 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1186 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:

    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.

    containing the value 117.

    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@615 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added Davidson eigensolver (keyword eigensolver="dav") and restructured

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@592 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    New LDAx functional (LDA exchange only).
    
    Moved exx stuff around.  Same EXX class is now used for both self-consistent and non self-consistent exx.  Self-consistent exx seems to work for all-electron calculations, but not quite for PAW.  Note also that it may not work in parallel mode.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@523 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@496 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@455 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5313 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4962 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Bugfix which closes #121. This is what happens when you borrow someone else's stuff without asking. In eigensolvers/eigensolver.py the interim function H used the work arrays allocated by Operator in hs_operators.py, but the size didn't always match. In the case of ticket 121, this lead to a return value of shape (125,29,29,29) rather than the correct (120,29,29,29). Implemented a little function in hs_operators called suggest_temporary_buffer which should *always* be used outside of hs_operators (the RM-DIIS eigensolver still doesn't respect this). Also removed an obsolete argument to allocate/estimate_memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4397 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed bugs in state parallelization related to mixed blocked/strided grouping of bands. Implemented BandDescriptor to encompass both types of state parallelization, but always use blocked grouping by default.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2207 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The same work-array is now used for both orthonormalization and
    subspace-diagonalization - and it's only allocated once.
    
    The RMM_DIIS class now uses the new Overlap class.
    
    There is also some code added (not used right now) for:
    
    1) Not rotating and keeping the large Htpsit_nG array, but instead
    recalculating it when needed.  This will be faster for large systems.
    
    2) Doing the orthonormalization and subspace-diagonalization with
    smaller work-arrays.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1323 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    new initialization scheme for eigensolvers
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1284 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3700 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    new localized functions integrate "the wrong way", i.e.
    
    newlfc.integrate2(psi_nG, c_nM, q=q)
    
    stores in c_nM, the values
    
    c_nM = <Phi_M|psi_n>
    
    which is of coarse consistent with the weird definition
    
    P_ni = <pt_i|psi_n>
    
    but not what you would expect.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3700 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    new localized functions integrate "the wrong way", i.e.
    
    newlfc.integrate2(psi_nG, c_nM, q=q)
    
    stores in c_nM, the values
    
    c_nM = <Phi_M|psi_n>
    
    which is of coarse consistent with the weird definition
    
    P_ni = <pt_i|psi_n>
    
    but not what you would expect.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5784 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introduce keyword 'parallel' to GPAW, which should later replace
    'parsize', 'parsize_bands' and 'parstride_bands'.  This is a dictionary
    much like 'convergence' used to specify parallel options.  Parallel
    options for scalapack can now be specified this way.  More options to be
    added as necessary.
    
    Create OrbitalDescriptor in paw.py when parameters are parsed. FD-mode
    wavefunctions objects now get an orbital descriptor, too, as it is used
    during initialization.  Avoid using extra_parameters everywhere to check
    for blacs (doing that still works, but is not mandatory anymore)
    
    Fixed bug in lcao/BLACS calculations with periodic boundary conditions.
    
    Fixed bug related to keyword argument utility.

    Allow setups to have no pseudo-core density, and no projector functions.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6851 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented full BLACS support for FD calculations. Finalized concept of Kohn-Sham layouts (KSL) and merged the diagonalizer classes from the FD/LCAO eigensolvers into it. These KSL also do inverse cholesky decomposition in the FD case, so they can no longer just be called diagonalizers, but rather, they are in charge of handling the interplay between BandDescriptor and GridDescriptor quantities pertaining to the Kohn-Sham representation. MatrixOperator now requires a KSL in order to create a descriptor for the band-by-band matrix or BLACS equivalent. This is created by PAW during initialize. Also updated the relevant unit tests where appropriate. The old ScaLAPACK interface is marked for deprecation, but has been retained for now. Note that the command-line argument sl_inverse_cholesky is without meaning in the new BLACS context.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6103 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Introducing a concept of 'Kohn-Sham layouts' which is to be responsible for parallel interplay between band and domain communicator layouts of the Kohn-Sham representation in both LCAO and FD mode. The thought/reality is that BLACS-alternatives of such layout classes will manage the more intricate aspects like linear algebra and redistributors by rediving from the base non-BLACS classes. Rename BlacsBandDescriptor to BlacsBandLayout and similar for BlacsOrbitalDescriptor.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6052 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    add timings to various possibly-time-consuming operations
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@6005 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Seperated out old ScaLAPACK and serial LAPACK debug interface. Unfortunately, not very pretty. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK in LCAO code, since this is not needed with the new BLAC. Deprecated old ScaLAPACK's inverse cholesky in real-space code to make way for new BLACS code. Also, sl_inverse_cholesky rarely got used as serial Cholesky is fine up to N=3500. Implemented simultaneous: spin, band, and domain parallelization in real-space code using old ScaLAPACK.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5999 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Treat the user a bit more gently

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7223 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented --sl_default and --sl_lcao command line arguments and made the GPAW 'parallel' dictionary keyword reflect these four possible ScaLAPACK/BLACS arguments. Deprecated the parsize, parsize_bands and parstride_bands keywords as they are now contained in the aforementioned 'parallel' keyword. There are still two points which need to be addressed: Lines 980-982 in wavefunctions.py regarding which Kohn-Sham layout to use for LCAO as we don't have access to the 'parallel' parameter from there, and line 173 in eigensolver.py when --sl_diagonalize is unequal to --sl_inverse_cholesky as the latter is passed to the _shared_ instance of MatrixOperator, hence there's a mismatch between the internal BlacsBandMatrixDescriptor and the Kohn-Sham layout used by the diagonalizer -- To be addressed ASAP.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3688 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fixed bug leading to unwanted density mixing in TDDFT. Unfortunate calls to paw.set_positions in TDDFT.__init__ causes density to be mixed twice with a BaseMixer before mixing is disabled by overwriting with a DummyMixer. Most likely, the effect was negligible, but it's a bug nonetheless.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    Fix the problem with projections becomig garbled if set_positions is called more than once. When the call to set_positions is initiated, it's important that the base class resets positions_set to False until after the (superfluous) call to allocate_projections where it's set back to True by the bottom-most child class. Closes #137.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5309 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5308 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Get rid of memory leak and/or prevent segfault; another case of buggy MPI documentation causing buggy code. Apparently MPI_Testall will actually deallocate requests if all are complete, which directly contrasts the behaviour of MPI_Test. As a result, comm.test(req) must always be followed by comm.wait(test) or comm.waitall([test]) to free MPI buffers, but non-zero return of comm.testall(reqs) must NOT be followed by comm.waitall(reqs) as this will lead to segfaults. Altough this behavoiur is now documented, it seems a bit counter-intuitive.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5304 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Forgot that Python 2.4 does not have a built-in all. On a related note, Communicator.testall still segfaults for some reason
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5302 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implement C backend to MPI_Testall, update Python interface and add a missing return. Added an interim MPI_Ibarrier-like function which can work both as a non-blocking barrier and a blocking barrier with a time-out limit. Closes #156 by using the blocking barrier in the test suite with a time-limit of 1 minute, after which the test suite indirectly invokes an MPI_Abort.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5299 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4214 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Extended parsize parameter and --domain-decomposition command line argument to allow a single int (usually tuple of 3 ints). This is especially usefull when trying to control the creation of communicators/distribution of cpus in a more general and less grid-specific sense. Running '$ mpirun -np 4 gpaw-python test.py --domain-decomposition=4' can be used to force all tests into parallel-over-domain-only scenarios, yet still adapting the parsize_c 3-tuple to fit the various grids (4x1x1 in some cases, 2x2x1 in others etc.), thus avoiding most grid-too-small errors.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4206 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Segregated new check_atoms method into a seperate function which doesn't require a PAW instance and just returns a boolean instead of raising a RuntimeError (which PAW.check_atoms still does). Method didn't alter the class, thus is shouldn't be a member function.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4141 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Fix bad broadcast_string scope of dtype int8 from NumPy.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4107 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Member function PAW.distribute_cpus does not depend on self at all, so it's cleaner to segregate it and turn it into a free-for-all function in mpi/__init__.py. This way, we don't need to create a GPAW instance just to obtain the communicators for parallel testing.

    Improvements to the MPI module: Backported the improvements made to
    the Asap.mpi module since that module was copied from GPAW.
    
    1) Keyword arguments for optional arguments.
    
    2) More reduction operators, and more data types for the reduction operators.
    
    3) Sanity checks moved from Python to C, and also enabled when not in
    debug mode.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1961 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma

    New Br setup based on reference data from http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.1574317;
    reference dipole moment for I-Br ignored because does not look converged
      X-Y| r [A]|   ref|   [%]| w [1/cm]|    ref|   [%]| m [D]|   ref|   [%]|
    Br-Br| 2.352| 2.352|   0.0|    294.0|  290.0|   1.4| 0.000| 0.000|   0.0|
    Br-Cl| 2.203| 2.205|  -0.1|    397.2|  395.3|   0.5| 0.546| 0.576|  -5.3|
     Br-F| 1.820| 1.813|   0.4|    622.0|  612.8|   1.5| 1.483| 1.483|  -0.0|
     H-Br| 1.438| 1.436|   0.1|   2532.0| 2512.9|   0.8| 0.754| 0.750|   0.5|
     I-Br| 2.540| 2.555|  -0.6|    245.9|  233.3|   5.4| 0.000| 0.000|   0.0|
    
    Results obtained with:
    scripts/XY.py -v --mode=calculate --spacings="\[0.14\]" Br

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4837 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    There are two modes now. Domain which is the older mode. Probably still useful for TDDFT. The new mode is for band parallelization in DFT. Ranks are ordered X,Y,Z, and bands. By specifying X,Y,T,Z you mean: I want to use Z dimension for band parallelization and T dimension for Z domains. Program is very convoluted, but hopeful others will figure out how to simpifly.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1524 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1343 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    svn used for ASE; closes #10
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1208 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    gpaw-nightly fixed; closes #1
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1201 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    Member function PAW.distribute_cpus does not depend on self at all, so it's cleaner to segregate it and turn it into a free-for-all function in mpi/__init__.py. This way, we don't need to create a GPAW instance just to obtain the communicators for parallel testing.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@558 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    Circumvent a small bug in Python 2.4 trace/coverage module, which results in zero'th-line entries for coverage of empty files (like __init__.py of zero bytes) although line-numbers are technically one-indexed. I have no idea what causes this as trace.py are nearly identical in the Python 2.4 and 2.5 releases, but the latter does not exhibit this behaviour.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5282 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added script for nightly generation of test coverage information. For parallel runs, coverage information is recorded for each core and subsequently merged into one file, which can be converted directly to .cover files by a simple command-line invokation. Additionally, test coverage information can be aggregated from several runs (e.g. with different parallelization) by sequentially running it. Closes #148 -  we still need to schedule these runs though.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5099 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    This was a very subtle bug introduced when scalapack_redist was generalized to allow the complex type. When matrices are redistributed between different blacs grids, we do not require that the matrices exist on the union of the blacs processor grids. In other words, we permit the None type on processors in the blacs grid which do not contain the source matrix. None does not contain a dtype of real or complex; but we need all the processors in the blacs grid to either call the real or complex redist function. This is neatest workaround possible. Another possible was to force the creation of empty arrays outside the blacs grid, this is even more confusing and wastes memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4758 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    where arch is the architecture of the machine where the test was run.
    
    The changes in c-code treat now the Numeric arrays as long integers,
    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    second derivatives of Exc interface
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@128 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added Copyright statements to C-code
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5447 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added a C function to convert the z-ranges 'G_b' used by Sphere->Spline into linear indices 'indices_gm' for np.take/np.put on a grid region enclosed by a given box. I did some timing and it turns out that transferring 'A_gm' via 'G_b' to 'work_mG' is a lot faster when done 'np.put(work_mG, indices_gm, A_gm)' as opposed to 'n=0; for a,b in zip(G_b[::2],G_b[1::2]): for m,box_G in enumerate(box_mG): np.put(box_G, range(a,b), A_gm[n:n+(b-a),m]); n+=b-a'. This is usefull for speeding up NewLFC-support in the exact inverse S operator.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4380 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    #include <Python.h>
    #include <math.h>

    {
      const double C = 2 * M_PI;

    }

    find existing way to do that for a simple function argument, e.g.
    def f(a):
      b = ...
      a, b = b, a # does not work, creates a new variable a
      swap(a,b) # does the job

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5447 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5308 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Get rid of memory leak and/or prevent segfault; another case of buggy MPI documentation causing buggy code. Apparently MPI_Testall will actually deallocate requests if all are complete, which directly contrasts the behaviour of MPI_Test. As a result, comm.test(req) must always be followed by comm.wait(test) or comm.waitall([test]) to free MPI buffers, but non-zero return of comm.testall(reqs) must NOT be followed by comm.waitall(reqs) as this will lead to segfaults. Altough this behavoiur is now documented, it seems a bit counter-intuitive.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5304 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implement C backend to MPI_Testall, update Python interface and add a missing return. Added an interim MPI_Ibarrier-like function which can work both as a non-blocking barrier and a blocking barrier with a time-out limit. Closes #156 by using the blocking barrier in the test suite with a time-limit of 1 minute, after which the test suite indirectly invokes an MPI_Abort.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5299 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added Python interface for MPI_Test and cleaned out cart_create interface, which was removed in r5238.

    In the wave function IO several sends are posted before the corresponding
    receives. This causes problems in some architectures (at least Cray XT)
    so it is better to use syncronous send (MPI_Ssend)

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1252 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Hello!
    
    Lately, I have been commenting and testing the gllb-code. The work is not yet done, but i realized that I have to
    keep up with the current version to make things easier in the future.
    
    Following things have changed:
    
    -For convience, I removed the kli.py from the main directory, and created new gllb directory and split
    the kli.py to several logical files. I have tried to write to code as general as possible, so in principle
    the code should be easy to expand.
    
    -The commenting and testing is not done, so do not rely on the results.
    
    -For some reason, the convergence is rather poor at first. This needs to be investigated, maybe plotting the
    3D-potentials and densities. This might have something to do with the fact that I am doing linear mixing
    for Vxc-potential, while the code is doing pulay mixing for density (and density matrices). I know a way to tests
    wheter this is true.
    
    -The parameter list from read_setup is getting larger. I generalized the setup-part for gllb in such way that
    any argument from xml file starting with GLLB_ will be stored to one dictionary, which will be passed
    on to XCNonLocalCorrections.
    
    -I use factory design pattern to get the correct type of "non-local"-functional.
    
    -I expanded the Slater potential calculation in KLI using legendres polynomials, so Function1D.py class in not
    needed. It is still needed in some parts of my experimental codes so I will not remove it at least now.
    
    -I removed the non-working 3D-KLI at least for now.
    
    Feel free to give comments and critique about the implementation.
    
    Best Regards,
    Mikael Kuisma

    In test.py, the timigs are now written to timings.pickle.arch file,
    where arch is the architecture of the machine where the test was run.
    
    The changes in c-code treat now the Numeric arrays as long integers,
    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    implemented c function to calculate derivatives of integrals (d/dR) <phi_mu | v(r) phi_nu> using new localized functions.  LCAO code fully migrated to new LFCs.  In a related matter, LCAO force calculations no longer scale ridiculously with system size.  Added verbose macros for spherical harmonic derivatives in c code, plus python code to generate these macros.

    where arch is the architecture of the machine where the test was run.

    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    def f(a):
      b = ...
      a, b = b, a # does not work, creates a new variable a
      swap(a,b) # does the job

    Remove compiler warnings and do not overwrite memory.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@7369 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    This is was a pretty serious bug. We were overwriting memory. We made an arrive of size [5][5] and then zeroed out up to [7][7]. This bug was introduced over 1 year ago, see https://trac.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/changeset/5216. I think want we may want to do is simply zero out up to [5][5], but I am hesistant to make the modification as it could adversely affect other parts of the code.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    where arch is the architecture of the machine where the test was run.
    
    The changes in c-code treat now the Numeric arrays as long integers,
    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1953 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1270 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Backporting LibXC fix for B3LYP bug causing segfault on some architectures.
    Closes #165 and now yields (nearly) identical results across architectures.
    
    Line 44 in hyb_gga_xc_b3lyp.c passes a pointer to XC(hyb_gga_type) when
    calling XC(lda_c_vwn_set_params), which expects a XC(lda_type) pointer.
    This explains why the segfault complains that p->gga_aux[0] is 1 because
    doing (XC(lda_type)* p)->params->spin_interpolation=1 when p is XC(hyb_gga_type)*
    will access the wrong address in memory (hence also machine dependent).
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5599 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1618 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modifications for MGGA self-consistent. TPSS and revTPSS work for Gamma-point
    calculations a part from Li/Li2. K-points calculations have very poor convergence
    so far. Main modifications are the contribution to the hamiltonian in "add_non_local_terms"
    and the contribution to the Kinetic Energy in hamiltonian.py.
    The mgga contribution to the forces has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5447 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed OpenMP in the apply function operators.py and transformers.py because the overhead associated with the thread-safe version of MPI is too big.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2480 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@503 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added an option to choose between Gauss-Seidel and Jacobi relaxation methods. Default set to Gauss-Seidel.
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@460 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Modified relax to weighted Jacobi relaxation, also a new alternative
    form of the Jacobi relaxation.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@382 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The default Poisson solver uses now the Jacobi iteration for smoothing
    the solution in all multigrid levels
    
    Add a new keyword maxiter for the calculater which determines the
    maximum number of iterations to do
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@120 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Implemented Gauss-Seidel relaxations for the Poisson multigrid solver
    In class PoissonSolver there is now new subroutine iterate2, which
    performs couple of Gauss-Seidel iterations in all multigrid levels.
    As the new subroutine has not been thoroughly tested, the old subroutine
    iterate is still the default.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@898 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Removed translation-rotation boundary conditions.
    
    Why:
    
    * Nobody is using it.
    * It doesn't run in parallel.
    * Forces are not implemented.
    * It only works for 90 and 180 degrees.
    * It makes the code more complicated than it needs to be at this point.

    implemented c function to calculate derivatives of integrals (d/dR) <phi_mu | v(r) phi_nu> using new localized functions.  LCAO code fully migrated to new LFCs.  In a related matter, LCAO force calculations no longer scale ridiculously with system size.  Added verbose macros for spherical harmonic derivatives in c code, plus python code to generate these macros.

    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@586 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added 1D-AE-KLI which works for small atoms with fully occupied subshells.
    I think it also works (up to the spherically averaged potential) for
    atoms with partially filled shells, but you cannot compare the results
    to real atoms since, the all_electron.py does it's calculation is with
    fractional occupation numbers and spin-symmetrically.
    
    Is this enough for calculating setup's? The asymptiotical behaviour of
    KLI is -f_{HOMO}/r, (in B for example -0.16666/r) so it will create an
    error to at least the highest occupied orbital eigenvalues, '
    but maybe this isn't so important since the these orbitals are not used anyway.
    
    At some point, for example with Zn, the calcalation fails.
    Maybe this is due to the missing gaunt's coefficients that I am
    assuming to be zero.

    Initial work on the Allow-tests-to-be-run-in-parallel project.  The goal is that the tests sould run on at least 2 and 4 cores.
    
    Another long-term goal is to move the test directory from trunk/test to trunk/gpaw/test (like for ASE) so that the tests are always available.  Like for ASE, one should do "cd /tmp; gpaw-test.py" to run the tests, and the tests should not be required to clean up files.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1360 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    It is now possible to specify a density-mixer object.  The old "mix=(0.1, 5, 100)" is now:
    
      mixer=Mixer(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    or
    
      mixer=MixerSum(0.1, 5, weight=100)
    
    for spin-polarized calculations.  See example in test/mixer.py.

    In test.py, the timigs are now written to timings.pickle.arch file,
    where arch is the architecture of the machine where the test was run.
    
    The changes in c-code treat now the Numeric arrays as long integers,
    so that the code works also in architecture where long and int are of
    different size.

    test/wannier-hwire.py fixed: the problem in 'equal' was that result of (center[0] % hhbondlength) could be close to 0 or 0.9
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1170 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1112 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@3172 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5313 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    new localized functions integrate "the wrong way", i.e.
    
    newlfc.integrate2(psi_nG, c_nM, q=q)
    
    stores in c_nM, the values
    
    c_nM = <Phi_M|psi_n>
    
    which is of coarse consistent with the weird definition
    
    P_ni = <pt_i|psi_n>
    
    but not what you would expect.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2582 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    I've now implemented the core eigenvalue calculation using Janak's theorem.
    Since I've derived the expressions for my Master's thesis with help of developers guide and
    https://wiki.fysik.dtu.dk/gpaw/Eigenvalues_of_core_states
    I can post more detailed documentation next week.
    
    It is based on GLLB--classes since I need the eigenvalues especially for GLLB
    calculations. For testing purposed I introduced a functional labeled GLLBLDARCR,
    which is exactly the LDA functional, but with core eigenvalues calculated.
    
    For general core eigenvalue calculation, post-scf-xas or so, I offer the programming task to somebody else,
    since I'm rather busy with this GLLB stuff, but it should be relatively easy. Currently the eigenvalues
    are calculated on every iteration, since I will use them to make GLLB self consistent with core response also.
    
    BTW, Do you know any good references for testing? I did a turbomole calculation
    for H2O and got a value of -18.60729Ha for lowest occupied orbital, and
    corresponding calculation with GPAW yielded -18.60716Ha for O1s.
    
    BR,
    Mikael

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@5252 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1683 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric

    For non-periodic calculations, the arrays now only store the non-zero values.
    
    Domain-decomposed grids can now have different number of grid points on different CPU's
    
    A "--gpaw-trace" option has been added.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@497 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Major restructuring of the code.  A hamiltonian object and a density object has been introduced. The WaveFunction object is now a part of the Paw object (wf.py is gone).  random.py has been removed because it can shadow the random.py from the standard library.  The idiotproof option has been removed.  A bug in calculator.py was fixed.

    New io module added.   All the nasty NetCDF details are now hidden in gridpaw/io/netcdf.py and there is an alternative simple tar-file format implemented in gridpaw/io/tar.py.  This means that we can now use gpaw without having netCDF and Scientific installed.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2824 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    More timers for bandpar.py. Note that in my previous commit I incorrectly stated that bandpar.py uses the same amount of memory as what is done in GPAW. This is incorect because of temporary arrays used in the Numpy calls to dot and inner. I have also created bandpar2.py which is based solely on dgemm calls; this version should be equivalent to what is present in GPAW because there are no calls to numpy except the one Cholesky decomposition.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1683 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    sub directory for parallel tests
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1333 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.

    Using localized functions will now no longer use MPI group communicators and blocking calls to MPI_Reduce and MPI_Bcast.  Instead non-blocking sends/receives/waits are used.  This will reduce syncronization time for large parallel calculations.

    sub directory for parallel tests
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1333 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Merging new-interface branch (667:957) to trunk
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@958 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    The type of setups used is now written to the restart file.
    
    Introduced gd.zeros and gd.empty methods.
    
    Allocations of Numeric arrays has been switched from num.zeros to
    num.empty where this makes sence.  This has three purposes:
    
    1) It is much faster (especially for large arrays).
    2) I think it makes the code easier to read when when we are explicit
    about whether an array needs to be initialized to zero or not.
    3) It helps in finding some types of bugs.
    
    In debug mode, num.empty is replaced by a function that returns arrays
    containing the value 117.
    
    Restarting from file is now much faster.  Allocation of some big
    arrays and the calculation of localized orbitals is delayed to the
    point where a calculation (after a change of the atomic positions)
    starts.  I had to move some code to some strange places - I'm not
    proud of it!  I'll clean it up later.
    
    
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@508 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2202 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    One has to use the fermi level of the self-consistent calculation!
    
    The fermi levels are:
    -0.097401946858884855 (self-consistent)
    -1.2211481914949307 (harris calculation)
    
    So this is important! We should fix this bug soon.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2840 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Changed get_fermi_level to raise an error for ZeroTemperature calculations.
    Also removed dependence of dos/ldos methods on get_fermi_level. Thus they are now relative tothe vacuum level for ZeroTemperature calculations and to the average effective potential for finite temp.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@4223 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Added a possible platform_id string which can be set in customize.py
    
    If set, the platform id in the build directory will have this string appended.
    
    If used, one must set
    build/lib.<platform> in PYTHONPATH
    and
    build/bin.<platform> in PATH
    so that gpaw is knows where to look for _gpaw.so and gpaw-python respectively.

    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@2808 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    Now GPAW uses numpy instead of Numeric
    
    git-svn-id: https://svn.fysik.dtu.dk/projects/gpaw/trunk@1519 6419b465-d902-0410-997c-be2266baf723
    "tolerance" and "convergeall" keywords removed.  Use:
    
      convergence={'eigenstates': 1e-10}
    
    or
    
      convergence={'bands': 'all'}
    
    Default value is:
    
      {'energy': Convert(0.001, 'eV', 'Hartree'),
       'density': 1.0e-3,
       'eigenstates': 1.0e-9,
       'bands': 'occupied'}
    
    Also, the hydrogen.py test is fixed.
